column4: I have used rsync to copy a large amount of music from one server to another. however it has left out all the tracks with apostrophes in. what cp flags should I use just to fill in the blanks, i.e not overwrite files that are already present at the destination
what rsync command did you use originally?

that command looks good, and should work even with files that contain apostrophes. Have you tried running it again? rsync won't copy the same files twice if they are identical. Were there any error/warning messages?
so if you do e.g. ls -l "/mnt/slimserver/music/CDs/Bukka White/The Complete Sessions

well, everything looks pretty much like I expected it to. I can't really see why rsync would complain that certain files have 'vanished'. Can you run the rsync command again and paste some of the error messages so I can see the *exact* text when it goes wrong...
I don't quite know what I'm looking for, but what you report shouldn't happen during normal usage, which is why I want to see an example of the exact message. Sometimes the devil is in the details...
I'm stumped. Is there something you haven't told me e.g. something special about the source filesystem perhaps?
so the source is nfs mounted? Any error messages from nfs in dmesg? Any error messages on the nfs server maybe?
same question though, I guess. What happens if you try and cp a single 'troublesome' file by hand?
I am unable to type the filename
not sure what you mean. You mean it doesn't autocomplete?
well, it's just a guess at this stage, but I think your problem is actually on the smb server. Can you copy a whole directory using cp -r ? (No need for asterisks or wild card characters)
so you can successfully copy a filename containing an asterisk if you do it via nautilus?
sorry, I'm out of ideas. I've never seen this failure mode before. At least you have a workaround :-)
